columns.text: In this exercise, we are going to learn about pricing convertibles.

To start with, let us define conversion value.

The ability of a bond to be converted into common stocks is a feature of a special type of bond. The converted amount into common stock is the **conversion value** of the bond.

Here are the parameters to solve the problem: 


|Given | | 
|--|--| 
|Face Value of the Bond |$1,000 | 
|Yield | 8%| 
|Coupon Rate |2.3% | 
|Number of period |25 years |

The equation to solve the value of the bond is illustrated below:

  

$$\textbf{Value}=\text{Interest}\times\left[\frac{1-\left(1+\text{r}\right)^{-\text{n}}}{\text{r}}\right]-\left[\text{FV}\times\left(1+\text{r}\right)^{\text{-n}}\right]$$

Where: 

 - r - Yield
- n - Number of periods
- FV - Face Value

To start with, let us solve the annual interest payments: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Interest Payments}&=\text{Face Value}\times\text{Coupon Rate}\\[20pt]
&=\$1,000\times0.0230\\[20pt]
&=\$23
\end{aligned}$$

The coupon rate is multiplied by the face value to determine the interest payments. 

Thus, the annual interest payment is $23.

Now, using the equation in Step 4, the value of the bond is solved as follows: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Value}&=\$23\times\left[\frac{1-\left(1+0.08\right)^{-25}}{0.08}\right]-\left[\$1,000\times\left(1+0.08\right)^{-25}\right]\\[20pt]
&=\$23\times\left[\frac{1-\left(1.08\right)^{-25}}{0.08}\right]-\left[\$1,000\times\left(1.08\right)^{-25}\right]\\[20pt]
&=\$23\times\left[\frac{1-0.146018}{0.08}\right]-\left[\$1,000\times0.146018\right]\\[20pt]
&=\$23\times\left(\frac{0.854}{0.08}\right)-\$146.018\\[20pt]
&=\left(\$23\times10.675\right)-\$146.018\\[15pt]
&=\$245.525-\$146.018\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\$99.51}
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the value of the callable, convertible bond is $99.51.
